summary: Evelio Duque Miyar was a Cuban anti-communist who had past interactions with the CIA. The CIA provided him with assistance at one point but later terminated the relationship due to disagreements over operational control. In 1978, he opened a confectionery store across from the U.S. consulate in Guayaquil, Ecuador. The Guayaquil station requested traces on him, as he may have been involved in Cuban operations in the Miami area during the early 1960s. The station reported having no operational interest in him at the time.
significance: The documents suggest that Evelio Duque Miyar was a person of interest to the CIA due to his background as a Cuban anti-communist and his potential involvement in Cuban operations. His significance in the JFK context is not explicitly stated in the provided documents, but his past association with the CIA and potential involvement in Cuban operations might be relevant depending on the broader context of the investigation.
